summary.body: Hi everyone I need a bit of advice, please. I didn't mind the duck nesting last month and am a proud auntie to 11 ducklings in Mountjoy House lake, but two days ago, a wood pigeon started to nest in another window-box.  We shooed her away yesterday morning and discarded of the twig nest, but she and her mate came back that evening and she's refusing to be moved on, even when I use the mop or broom. In fact, she started snapping out, as to bite both objects. She backs into my favourite echyium (Canarian palm) to the extent that her wing hits it at a funny angle and it looks like she'll break her wing, which stops me from being more agressive towards her. I left her for the night but her mate came back and cooed again at 6am and I'm really shattered today, so have cancelled plans to go out to the flower market  I think I recall that you can prick the eggs. I don't know if she's laid yet, but the way she's biting out at the broom and not moving this time, implies she has one underneath her. Maybe if I put her rent up? Does anyone have any experience of what happens when the eggs hatch? Do your plants really die?  Any advice would be greatly appreciated. She is very sweet looking, the nest building exercise showed the devotion of her love-interest, but I'm really tired and grumpy today, and don't want to be like this for the next few weeks, otherwise it will be ME snapping everytime I see a mop or broom.
summary.subject: Wood pigeon dilemma

summary.body: Amid all the moans and groans we have living here, which this forum helps to bring to light, I feel we need a thread about all the wonderful things about the Barbican, which I hope you'll all add to so this might become the most prominent thread.  So I'll start the list, and please add to it or extrapulate on the points already made. 1. I love my home, with its corbusian dimensions and its south facing sitting room overlooking a garden. 2. I love being able to walk to work and to the West End, and home again.  3. I love my Sunday Walks though a quiet City of London down to St Paul's (sometimes stopping for evensong and other times walking on) across the bridge and along the river, back up again through the City to home again.  4. I love the wildlife on my door: wrens nesting in my window boxes; ducks, geese; falcons; gulls; ducks; blackbirds; wagtails; coots; moorhens ... to name but a few. 5. I love the gardens. Private, public spaces (especially the wildlife garden.  6. I love feeling safe, and having a police force for the city that respond to complaints about skateboarders with half the police station! 7. I love the Barbican Association; the way it fights on our behalf, produces great publications and most of all makes me feel I'll never have to worry about things going wrong here.  8. I love the Barbican arts center (or the theatre/cinema downstairs as we call it). 9. I love Barbicantalk. We exchange information, help out new residents, winge, moan, complain, have the occasional row, but ultimately, rare among internet forums it remains a place of polite communication.  10. I love the incredible rise of the Smithfields' Clerkenwell area -- we we first moved here there were no restaurants or bars open at the weekend, a total desert, and now we have on our doorstep one of the most vibrant parts of London and some of its great eateries.  11. I love the way people really care about the Barbican, and can become a bit obsessive about it (this threat: QED). 12. I love being equidistant to every London airport.  13. I love the CPA's, porters and cleaners, who always know what's going on; caring above and beyond the call of duty for our senior residents, knocking on doors (and breaking in if necessary if someone's not seen for a while). 14. I love having the corporation as a landlord. Never any problems.  !5. I love being a citizen of London (a freeman). Well, I could go on much longer, but I'll leave it now to others to add to the list.  x
summary.subject: Things I love about Barbican

summary.body: Hank and Dannii got off the train at Windsor and Eton Riverside station and made their way to the venerable boys school. Soon they were in the chapel, with its graceful arches and medieval wall paintings. Doesnt look too Brutalist to me, said Dannii. Surely you didnt acquire your taste for concrete while you were at Eton. Appearances, my dear, may be deceiving. You have no doubt noticed the exquisite fan vaulting above you, and probably assumed, like most casual observers, that it dates back to the time of Henry VI. Yes, you took the words right from my lips. I took the module on Perpendicular Gothic at police college. Ahh, but there is a twist in the tale, purred Hank. The fan vaulting was actually added in 1959. And what do you think is behind its stone facing? Asbestos? No  pure concrete. I was a boy here when the rotting wooden ceiling was pulled out, and this marvel of 1950s ingenuity was constructed. You see, Dannii, I became a man here  a concrete man through and through. Gradually the fog was lifting, the pieces were falling into place, and there was light at the end of the tunnel. (Unfortunately Dannii had skipped the module on Avoiding Mixed Metaphors at police college.) Hank, I have only known you for a short time, but destiny has brought us together and there must be a reason. He had been admiring the misericords in the choir but rose and turned to face her. Yes, Dannii, it doesn't take much to see that the problems of two little people don't amount to a hill of beans in this crazy world. As time goes by   No, no, no, Hank. Get a grip. There is a Brutalist secret and it is here somewhere but we just cant see it. I had a dream! The quote of the day! Martin Luther King? No, Larry Crogan on Barbicantalk FM. I dreamt about his morning show. And he said something about the playing fields of Eton.  An allegorical dream! So thats why you kept muttering theres no place like home on the train this morning. Thass wicked! Wed better get over to those playing fields straightaway. Soon enough they were watching the boys training for the Berkshire Cup. You know, Dannii, I probably learned more here than in any lessons. Wickets, beamers, rippers, dibbly-dobbly bowlers . . .  What ARE you on about? Whats any of this got to do with Brutalism? Well, a cricket match is a lot like life. Nothing happens for ages, and then it all happens at once. It doesnt do much for me, Hank. Now, darts is something I can really get my teeth into. Did I ever tell you about the Advanced Darts module at police college? Sadly not, Dannii. Look, I know a little wine bar in Windsor, where you can tell me all about it. It was getting dark when their train eventually pulled into Waterloo. As they got off the train, Dannii said to Hank, You know, Ive never been to a cricket match before. The funny thing is, cricket whites arent really white. I mean, I suppose they are white when theyre new, but they sure do attract grass stains. Its a bit of a misnomer isnt it? Theres more colour to cricket than I would have guessed. Hank sighed and changed the subject. So near and yet so far. I really thought we were going to get deeper into the heart of Brutalism today. But we travelled all that way and then just sort of hit a brick wall. Well, it has been very pleasant in any case. Lets round off the day with a walk down by the river. And so off they went towards the South Bank. TO BE CONTINUED

summary.body: The language in what follows is not mine.  I have taken it straight from the back right hand side of the newly-distributed PODIUM which claims - in its stap line - to be "From the Barbican Centre for Residents".  It is death by a thousand cuts (taken in conjunction with all the other development works around and invading the quality of life of the Estate) and written in the kind of jargon that makes NEWSPEAK warm, cuddly and comprehensible. "As part of the Frobisher Redevelopment works, staff on Level 6 of the Barbican Centre are required to decant to other office spaces. The majority of Level 6 staff will be moving to a temporary site in Bonhill Street and the remainder, who cannot leave the site due to the nature of their work, will be located in two modular buildings located on the Sculpture Court." "The delivery of the modular buildings is currently scheduled for Sunday 18 November. The delivery is certified as an abnormal load, due to its size, therefore the Metropolitan Police will only allow this to take place overnight or on a Sunday. With the residents in mind, the Barbican Centre did want want the delivery to be overnight and therefore Sunday was chosen as the only other option." For those of you old enough to remember BEYOND THE FRINGE in 1961 you may already hear the cackle of Dudley Moore in the background as I continue in my best Alan Bennett (or Peter Cook or Jonathan Miller voice) because this piece of idiocy would have been fought over by all the cast as it is such a gem. "It is necessary to close Silk Street to allow the delivery to take place; road closure will be between the hours of 9am and 6pm. The modular buildings will then be craned into the Sculpture Court." "The mobile crane will arrive on Silk Street at 8am and will be set up in preparation for the first lift at 9am. Units will then be unpacked and attached to the crane which will lift the unit from Silk Street on to Level 3. Power pallet trucks will then be used to skate the units into position on the Sculpture Court." "There will be a total of 14 lifts taking place throughout the day and they will take approximately five minutes each....To address the environmental issue of noise, delivery vehicles will switch off engines between arrival and departure and the crane's engine will be switched off when not in operation." I've checked my blood pressure. Yes....it is up.  I do not want to use bad language on this site so I will let others scream the words for me as they read this (or as they react to the PODIUM delivery through their letterboxes). The convenient fiction - and it is one the City of London and our representatives on it to go along with -  seems to be that people do not live in the Barbican Estate, not really. And - if they do - then they bugger off at the weekend. And for those who stay then "Hey, you'll wish you hadn't." The interest I declare - in this posting - is that, living in a flat in Shakespeare looking out over the Sculpture Court, means that Calypso and I will have to live through the stated (and probably under-estimated)14 lifts on that Sunday and we are being treated as if we were not here and shouldn't be here.  The trouble is it makes me want to hire a mobile crane and some modular buildings and to go and spend a weekend - maybe over the Christmas/New Year period of goodwill - doing exactly this close to the people who think this is OK....but that way lies madness, war and the destruction of civilisation.  I'd better get back in my box and keep taking the tablets.
summary.subject: Just when you thought it was safe to sleep in

summary.body: Like the model on which it is based, this literary exercise could run on and on interminably. You are forewarned!  Professor Tom Hank Hangman was just dropping off to sleep when the phone rang. He picked it up and a voice said Come now to Bunyan Court . . . you have been chosen. Suddenly he sat up, wide awake. Could this be the signal he had been waiting for all these years? Had it finally happened? Would he soon gain admittance to that dark and hallowed place which so few had seen but of which so much had been spoken? Would someone please answer one of these questions so we can move on to the next paragraph?  There could be no doubt. The message could only mean one thing. What had been prophecied so many years ago was now within his grasp: the Hangman name had arrived at the top of the list, and tonight he would get his own baggage store on the Barbican estate.  He quickly left his flat in Defoe House and made his way to Bunyan Court. Along the way a small figure in a hoodie passed him, and whispered something. It sounded like Latin. Hangman may well have been the only Latin scholar at Oxford who had written an award-winning study of 20th-Century Brutalism, but he ignored the stranger; surely it was just one of those Spanish students from the YMCA going out to recycle his empties, and he was probably just saying hello or asking whether he had a spare euro. But there was no one else in Bunyan Court garden. He walked round and round but not a soul. Finally the hooded figure returned. Ola! Buenas noches Hangman called out. I beg your pardon? It was a womans voice, not a mans, and it was not Spanish. It sounded more North European than Mediterranean. German? Danish? Estonian? He finally placed the accent: Crouch End.  Sorry, I thought you were going to the YMCA. I am. We got a call about a disturbance there. Im WPC Brown  Dannii Brown. Im Professor  I mean, Im Hank. I was hoping to meet someone here. Wouldnt you have a bit more success over in the Shakespeare? The light is better there, too. No, no, thats not what I meant. Im not looking for a one-night stand, I am in search of something far more enduring and fulfilling  something with depth and breadth. Dannii lowered her gaze, and thought: It must be him. The Initiate. Why else would he be wandering around Bunyan Court garden at this hour, dressed in his jimjams and floppy bunny slippers? She spoke just three words: Chamberlin Powell Bon Hanks head spun round. What an extraordinary thing to say! It all started to add up: the hooded figure, the mock-Latin words, Bunyan Court at precisely 11.11 on a Tuesday evening, and Dannii spelled with two Is. She must be the Grandmaster. Now he just needed to find the right response; he concentrated his Eton-educated, Chateau-Margaux-addled brain and spoke: Alpenhorn  climb  elbow. TO BE CONTINUED
summary.subject: The Defoe 'C' Code

summary.body: Newer members of this forum may wish to read earlier installments of the Parable before reading this posting:   ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ It had been ages since I had seen my neighbour 1179. He had finally been released from Pols Bonne Chambers, and had been signed off as fully re-educated. Never again would he even dream of replacing his original skirting boards, nor would anyone ever hear him muttering about smells emanating out of his Garchey. He was now a Barbicanite through and through, and he would adhere to the listings guidelines like a limpet to a two-ton anchor.  The Committee had even found him employment; he had been appointed into the new role of Lake Guardian, which had been created after the lakes and fountains were renovated last year. One fine morning I decided to track him down by the lakeside. Greetings, adherer, he said. And be you ever grateful for your Listing, I replied, using the Committees recommended salutation. Nice to see that youve come back from Pols Bonne Chambers. Oh yes, the Chambers were fabulous but nothing can compare with living here, right in the beating heart of Brutalism, he said. Youve found yourself a great position here as Lake Guardian. A stroke of luck, wasnt it? The Lakes are such an integral part of the original Barbican vision. If they werent here, the whole place wouldnt be so reminiscent of Venice, would it. Absolutely! And it was so clever of the conservationists to ensure that mosquitoes would now be able to breed here, just as in La Serenissima itself. Mosquitoes? But there are no mosquitoes here; havent you read the notices which have gone up in each block? Samples have been taken from the lake and there are absolutely no mosquitoe larvae. Its those insurgents again, always stirring up trouble. They are determined to undermine the Brutalist vision, and are surreptiously dropping nits onto peoples heads from one of the balconies of Shakespeare Tower. But were on to them now and will soon put a stop to this. It was so reassuring to hear 1179 speak this way. The trainers at Pols Bonne Chambers had done wonders. Here was surely a man who put the rut into Brutalism. I asked him about the rumours concerning the lake plantings. Oh yes, those silly people who say that the lake in front of the Arts Centre was never meant to be planted with two rows of greenery. Have they never seen a Brutalist waterhedge? The ignorance of these people is just staggering. I had to agree that one heard a lot of nonsense spouted by the uninformed. And the way people moan about the green slime in the lakes now. Did anyone ever say Brutalism was meant to be clean? I think there are some idiots out there who cant tell the difference between Minimalism and Brutalism. That slime has been carefully cultured to counter the antiseptic characteristics of water features in suburban developments. Whats right for Kingston is certainly NOT right for EC2. Hear, hear I said. Where have these moaners been living all their lives  on the moon? Come to think of it, the surface of the moon is actually rather Brutalist. Maybe the Almighty spent some time in Pols Bonne Chambers and got some inspiration there, halfway through the Creation. Interesting theory; worth further study. Must get going now; Im doing my weekly patrol for terracotta containers on the balconies  theyre like weeds: just when you think you are rid of them, a couple more crop up somewhere else and have to be eradicated before they spread further. Who in their right mind would think that you can put terracotta next to hammered concrete? Nice chatting to you, I said. A very good day to you, sir - and may you always be Adhering,  he said as he strolled off.
summary.subject: the parable of the lake

summary.body: Professor Hank Hangman repeated himself: Alpenhorn  climb  elbow. "Sorry love, wrong anagram. Have another go, said WPC Dannii Brown. Hank tried again: lets see, an anagram for Chamberlin, Powell, Bon. Bunyan Court. Garden. Lake. What swims in a lake. Who re-did the Barbican lakes. Who paid for it. Got it! How noblemen bill carp Well done, my little Hanky. You are worthy. Untold secrets of the Barbican past, present and future will be revealed to you (albeit in the most obtuse and improbable ways). Hank fell to the ground, and kissed the brick paving of the Upper Podium: what more could I ask for? Brutalism de-mystified, a dishy WPC who is actually a grandmaster, and Waitrose opening  truly, we are bless-ed! He asked, What message do you bare?, or rather What message do you bear? What a loser, Dannii thought, and said Come with me.  They headed east. But soon their path was blocked. A hideous apparition stood before them. Ugly beyond words, silent as the grave. They halted.  Good lord, that Barbican Exhibition Hall walkway is an eyesore Hank said. They made their way round it, entered the Arts Centre, and left it on level 2 by Searcys. Soon they were crossing the bridge under Gilbert House. Danni pulled Hanks sleeve. Look there, in front of St Giles Cripplegate. Is it truly amazing? Err . . . yes, well Ive always thought St Giles was lovely, said Hank. But its not a-Mazing, is it? Where is the labyrinth? Hank thought back to a discussion on barbicantalk a couple of years ago. Yes, there were plans to create a labyrinth on the forecourt of the church. But they never came to anything. Dannii was getting impatient. There is no labyrinth, because they didnt want us to know the truth. They thought we would solve the puzzle and the secret would be out. What secret? The secret that, should it ever be told, would change the lives of every single Barbican resident, and indeed cause the history books of our time to be re-written. Brutalism is not what it appears to be. Just stop right there, Dannii, I wrote the book on Brutalism. Hank, Hank, Hank  you went to Eton, right (I got full marks in the Accent Placement module at police college)? Perhaps thats a good place to start looking for the secret. TO BE CONTINUED

Its Larry Crogan here on Barbicantalk FM, and its a fine morning. Early morning drizzle will clear up and leave us with lovely grey skies for the rest of the day. Its a busy day here on the Barbican Estate, and here are some activities to look out for. Professor Hank Hangman looked around his bedroom in Defoe House. Was it already time to get up? What strange dreams he had had. A WPC named Dannii, a foreign accent, whispers in the darkness, a gentle tug on his sleeve and then  . . .  he could still feel a tingle of excitement as he remembered how his fingertips had caressed those sinuous curves, so inviting and yet curiously unyielding. Yes, nothing could beat Frobisher Crescent for sheer sensuousness. After hed said goodbye to Dannii, he had partaken of a few delicious moments there, conducting his own fingertip search of its hammered concrete.  Crogan droned on: At 11am the ducks, pigeons and geese around the lake will be fed pieces of bread. At 11.15 the Dont Feed the Birds group will meet to count the signatures on their petition. Garchey Lovers meet at noon in Willoughby, and Garchey Haters meet at noon as well - but at a safe distance, in Lauderdale Tower. Then at 4pm theres a workshop on how to set up your Freeview box and video recorder with the cable TV system. Get there early folks, as this one is bound to fill up. And bring a sandwich as this workshop lasts three hours. The lines are ringing already, so lets take our first call. Puzzled in the Postern, you are now talking live on Barbicantalk FM. Could someone please tell me why there is a stop in the Beech Street Tunnel for bus 153 when it is going eastwards, but theres no longer a stop in the tunnel for the bus on its westward journey? Well, people! Now thats a topic that will run and run. Dont be shy; pick up the phone and call us now on Barbicantalk FM. In the meantime, heres the quote of the day. Its from the Duke of Wellington: The battle of Waterloo was won on the playing fields of Eton. Hank sat up with a jolt. He was meant to be going to Eton today with Dannii. Click. Its 7am on Tuesday the 30th of May, and you are listening to Today on BBC Radio Two . . .  Professor Hank Hangman looked around his bedroom in Defoe House. What a bizarre dream he had had, all about a radio station called Barbicantalk FM. And people with the strangest things on their minds.  Whatever it had all meant, he did know one thing: he would never buy another Robin Williams video, even if they were going very cheap at the St Giles book fair. TO BE CONTINUED

summary.body: What a day it had been for WPC Dannii Brown and Professor Tom Hank Hangman. His alarm clock had gone off in the middle of a dream which seemed to have a hidden meaning, and the two of them had taken the train to Eton in search of Brutalisms deepest secret, only to find mock-Gothic fan vaulting and a group of boys playing cricket. It was all so . . . undramatic.  Now they were having a stroll along Londons South Bank. Evening had come, and people were rushing about purposefully.  Its rather like the Barbican here, isnt it? said Hank. A cluster of world-class arts venues in the heart of the city, so convenient for people to drop into after a long days work. Dannii nodded. Yes, but there seems to be something missing. Whats that? Well, everyone is just headed towards their destination. No one is hesitating or asking for directions. Everything is arranged in a line along the river, theres decent signage, and NO ONE IS GETTING LOST. The Thames pathway curved towards the National Theatre, and Hank stopped in his tracks. Thats absolutely disgusting. Sir Denys Lasdun must be rolling in his grave. How can this desecration be allowed? Dannii followed his gaze towards the theatre, which was a lovely purplish colour tinged with green on one edge. What do you mean? Its those obscene lights which are bathing the concrete in colour. Everyone knows that Brutalist buildings were meant to be the colour of raw concrete. Dont they have any respect for Lasduns vision? Get a grip, Hank. Look, lets call it a day, shall we?  The next day Hank decided to descend to the bowels of Defoe House and see the baggage store he had recently been allocated. It was fairly gloomy down there, but he spotted what looked like an abandoned kitchen cabinet in the corner. He recognized it as a bit of one of the original Barbican kitchens  which are said to be the very first fitted kitchens in the UK. Shame that someone has painted it red  almost the colour of Waitrose morello cherry preserve, in fact  otherwise Id bring it over to the salvage store and it could be put to good use. Perhaps the paint will come off easily.  He scratched away with his fingernail but the paint didnt flake at all. He looked closer; it was almost as if the cabinet had been finished in red rather than the obligatory white. He opened the door, and on the inside of the frame there was a number: 0 0 1 2 3 5. There was a further number but it wasnt legible.  Hank went back upstairs and called Dannii. Theres something odd over here, Dannii, and I need you to exercise your investigative powers. He told her about the cabinet. Thats so frustrating, Hank. Im sure that number means something. You are the worlds foremost expert on Brutalism, so perhaps the meaning is buried in your subconscious. Was there something in that dream yesterday which you havent mentioned? Well, it all seemed rather nonsensical. Barbicantalk, Eton, Garchey, feeding the birds. Hold on, there was something about the Beech Street Tunnel, too. Lets meet up there and see if it will jog your memory, Dannii said. A few minutes later they were at the entrance to the tunnel, near Holmes Place. 0 0 1 2 3 5 . . . and then one more number. Ive got it! said Dannii. Me too! Its the Fibonacci Sequence. If you study the beige panels along this side of the tunnel, youll see that they occur in a mathematical pattern. Its deliberate! No, silly. Thats too obscure. Its the Pirelli Sequence  the tire marks going down the tunnel, and how many metres apart they are. At police college we learned how to track down stolen cars that way. Lets see where they lead! Off they went through the tunnel, down Silk Street, right round the Barbican and across London Wall until they came to the Guildhall Library. Yes, yes of course. The numbers must refer to a document in the reserve collection, said Hank. They went inside and approached the librarians desk. We are looking for a document from the 1950s, relating to the Barbican. The reference number is 001235 but we arent sure about the last number. The librarian slowly looked up. I have been waiting for you, grandmaster and acolyte. I will bring you the file. Please sit at that table behind the bookcase and let no one see you. After what seemed like an eternity, the librarian brought them an old-fashioned box file. Hank wiped off the dust and read the label: Deliberations of the Surface Rendering Committee, Barbican Estate.  He opened it quickly and the sheets inside fell across the table, light as air. Hank, what material did they use for these documents? Its so light, and almost transparent, and has this amazing texture? Is it papyrus, or vellum, or parchment? No, Dannii, its far more exotic than any of those. These are carbon copies. Its what people used before they had photocopiers or PDFs. Hank scanned through the documents. Its all about a struggle . . . between the Brutalists and . . . a kind of breakaway sect . . . the Reform Brutalists . . . theres testimony here from Chamberlin, Powell and Bon which Ive never seen before: And so, Mr Chamberlin, could you please tell this committee what colour you have chosen for Willoughby House? The hammered concrete shall be rendered entirely in chartreuse, my lords. And Andrewes House? Mr Powell spoke up. Ooooh, we rather fancied a kind of mauve, something a little heavier than a Mountbatten pink. And Lambert Jones Mews? Now it was Mr Bons turn. Viridian green. Definitely viridian. This is a fine Brutalist colour. I dont hold with that Reform Brutalist concept of unpainted concrete.  Hank slumped back into his chair. Ive always wondered why the railings in the Barbican are different colours; why not just an innocuous brown which would blend in so much better? The railings were the last survivors of the Brutalist creed. Yes, Hank, the Reform Brutalists triumph back in 1957 was all but complete. For us true Brutalists, the railings were all we could hold on to. Ive been wanting to tell you since I met you, but first I had to know whether your heart was true. Its all falling into place now, said Hank. The cricket whites at Eton  stained that vivid green. The National Theatre lit up all those colours at night. The kitchen cabinet the colour of morello cherry preserve   Yes, Waitrose will only sell that item to initiates who know to ask. For all these years, Ive followed false gods. Brutalism isnt about unadorned concrete. Its about COLOUR, great swathes of rich pigment which should be bathing every nook and cranny of our beloved estate. Im ruined; every lecture Ive given, every paper Ive published, Ill have to retract them all, every last one. Cheer up, Hank. Now that you know the truth, Im sure youll be able to re-invent yourself. Yes, Ill find a niche somewhere. Ive got it  Ill offer myself to Farrow & Ball as a consultant, and well launch the Brutalist Colour Collection. Well make a fortune!

I've moved now from my slightly dark flat in BJ to a little studio in JT and it's wonderful! The light, the big windows. The Barbican was an exceptional piece of '60s / '70s architecture.  When I come in from the east on the train after visting a friend I see so many bleak blocks of badness; some old and plenty new. Small mean windows and cheap construction. Now, just now 30/40 years later the Barbican kitchens are fading... that's a long time compared to the new brick boxes! I feel so at home here - curiously my current JT rented studio is directly opposite the flat I had when I first moved into ECx. summary.body: The following April 1 notice was put up in a Speed House lift but I am not sure it circulated much wider and I think it deserves to be preserved for posterity.   Pigeon control on the Barbican estate  Measures to reduce the numbers of wild pigeons on the Barbican Estate are proving successful with the introduction of pigeon pie in the Waterside caf. The weekly visits from the Harris hawk are ensuring that the pigeons are fully race-fit and the pies have now been authorised as low-fat by the Cripplegate healthy eating society.  To ensure a plentiful supply of pigeons we ask that if residents find a nest on their balcony, you keep your personal noise to a minimum.  We have been assured by Barbican engineers that the recent noises from running barbican fire alarm tests at the weekend, drilling for oil in Milton Court on unloading trucks at all hours are collectively and statistically less intrusive than the noise residents make playing Radio 3 at low volume with the windows closed.  Please respect your wildlife neighbours and please wear soft slippers indoors at all times. Feeding the pigeons is OK - but Waitrose only please. We have had some younger birds gagging on Somerfield tit-bits and remember  no fast food. If you want pigeon Foie Gras  Harrods can deliver a rather nice hamper of foods to stuff your pigeons with.  We do not recommend stuffing by force (gavage)  sp please just ask your birds politely to eat as much as they can.
